snippet.title: It's no longer 'Will it play in Peoria?,' but 'What's playing?'
snippet.description: Revitalization project brings museums and other attractions to the river's edge

snippet.title: 10 Things to Know for Today
snippet.description: Your daily look at late-breaking news, upcoming events and the stories that will be talked about today:

snippet.title: Brazil unveils $11 billion in 'legacy' budget
snippet.description: Brazilian government officials announced Wednesday that almost $11 billion (24.1 billion Brazilian reals) will be spent on major transportation and environmental projects, which they argue are not related to holding the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Olympics.

snippet.title: A used-book sale's swan song
snippet.description: A Bethesda school's beloved bookselling tradition decides

snippet.title: In Germany's east, an economic force emerged from the dust of the Berlin Wall
snippet.description: A generation after German reunification, the nation's east has been utterly transformed.

snippet.title: Newark Archdiocese yet to pay taxes in monument business
snippet.description: The Archdiocese of Newark in recent years quietly entered the headstone and mausoleum business, a lucrative venture for which the archdiocese acknowledges it must pay a particular state tax.

snippet.title: Officials in Yalta, Crimea, are nervous but hopeful about this year's tourism season
snippet.description: With tourism the backbone of the Crimean economy, officials fear visitors will stay away this summer.

snippet.title: Venezuela's Hugo Ch√°vez died a year ago, but the 'eternal commander' still won't be silenced
snippet.description: A year after his death, Hugo Chavez leaves Venezuelans angry, mourning and badly divided

snippet.title: For some Metro riders, the latest snow day is just like any other
snippet.description: With rail ridership down and bus service halted again, Metro says storm is a budget drain, but not crippling

snippet.title: In Ukraine, objections from Maidan slow naming of new cabinet
snippet.description: Parliamentary horse-trading continues amid unhappiness over familiar candidates for top posts.
